prompt:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

One woman from the population will be selected at random.

chartConfig.description: Histogram showing relative frequencies of heights of women, with mean 64.97 inches and standard deviation 2.66 inches

parts.description: Based on the histogram, what is the probability that the selected woman will have a height of at least 67 inches? Show your work.
parts.response: The probability is equal to the sum of the relative frequencies of the heights from 67 to 72.

parts.description: What is the area of the bar corresponding to a height of 67 inches in the graph, and what does the area represent in terms of probability?
parts.response: The bar corresponding to a height of 67 inches is a rectangle with base 1 (67.5 minus 66.5) and height 0.11. So the area is 0.11, which is also equal to the probability that a randomly selected woman has a height of 67 inches.

parts.description: Use the normal model and the relationship between area and relative frequency to find the probability that the randomly selected woman will have a height of at least 67 inches. Show your work.
parts.response: For a normal model with mean 64.97 inches and standard deviation 2.66 inches, the z-score for 67 inches is \(z = \frac{67 - 64.97}{2.66} ≈ 0.76\). Using area as probability, the area under the standard normal curve to the right of 0.76 is approximately 0.2236.

parts.description: Does your answer in part (c-i) match your answer in part (a)? If not, give a reason for why the answers might be different.
parts.response: The probability of 0.2236 is a little less than the answer in part (a) of 0.27 because there is less area in the tail of the normal curve than in the bars of the histogram.

parts.description: Give an example of a probability of H that can be found using the discrete model but not the normal model. Explain why.
parts.response: The probability that the selected woman has a height equal to 63 inches, \(P(H = 63)\), is an example of a probability that can be found with the discrete model as the area (or height) of the bar that corresponds to 63 inches. However, there is no area above a single number on the normal model.

parts.description: Give an example of a probability of H that can be found using the normal model but not the discrete model.
parts.response: The probability that the selected woman has a height greater than 63.5 inches, \(P(H > 63.5)\), is an example of a probability that can be found with the normal model by standardizing 63.5. However, it is not clear on the discrete model what the relative frequency of fractional heights might be.

prompt: The continuous random variable \(N\) has a normal distribution with mean 7.5 and standard deviation 2.5. For which of the following is the probability equal to 0?
reasoning: The normal model requires area to find probability. At the point 8, there is no interval and no area under the curve. No area technically means a probability of 0.

prompt: Clara recorded 50 numerical observations on a certain variable and then calculated the mean \(\bar{x}\) and the standard deviation \((s)\) for the observations. To help decide whether a normal model is appropriate, she created a chart showing intervals around the mean. In Clara's chart, the letters \((a), (b), (c), (d), (e)\) represent the number of observations falling in each interval. Which of the following list of counts for \(a), (b), (c), (d), (e)\), respectively, is the best indicator that the variable can be modeled with a normal approximation?
reasoning: For a normal approximation, about 68% of the 50 observations, or 34 observations, should fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean, as shown in this list. This list has 48 of the 50 observations (96%) falling within 2 standard deviations of the mean, which is close to what would be observed in a normal model (95%).

prompt: The distribution of time needed to complete a certain programming task is approximately normal, with mean 47 minutes and standard deviation 6 minutes. Which of the following is closest to the probability that a randomly chosen task will take less than 34 minutes or more than 60 minutes to complete?
reasoning: If \(x\) represents "the time needed to complete the task," then \(P(x < 34) + P(x > 60) = P\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma} < \frac{34-47}{6}\right) + P\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma} > \frac{60-47}{6}\right) = P\left(z < -\frac{13}{6}\right) + P\left(z > \frac{13}{6}\right) ≈ 0.0303\).

prompt: A machine is used to fill bags with a popular brand of trail mix. The machine is calibrated so the distribution of the weights of the bags of trail mix is normal, with mean 240 grams and standard deviation 3 grams. Of the following, which is the least weight of a bag in the top 5 percent of the distribution?

choices.value: 234 grams
240 grams
243 grams
246 grams
248 grams

reasoning: The upper 5% of the area under the standard normal curve is to the right of \(z ≈ 1.65\) (because \(P(z < 1.65) ≈ 0.95\)). The weight of a bag with that z-score is \(3(1.65) + 240 = 244.95\). Of the choices shown, 246 is the least value that is greater than 244.95.
